awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Studies in Biological Size and Shape Control
awd_abstract_narration: In this project, the PI will test a novel hypothesis that eukaryotic cells use wave fringe counting to measure their lengths and shapes. The project was inspired by an experiment showing that strong alternating electric fields disrupt mitosis in a way that is resonant at radio frequencies. The PI will bring ideas from physics, where it is well understood that fringe counting is the method for measuring lengths stable at large scales. The PI hypothesis that fringe counting work cells uses simulated inertia: a method commonly by human engineers in designing microchips and also playing role in biology in the functioning of the cochlea. The larger objective of the proposed research is to identify the meter sticks of life. The intellectual merit of the proposed research might lead to a fundamentally new understanding of cell regulatory machinery. A potential discovery that cells can and do measure lengths by means of fringe counting would open a new chapter in our understanding of morphogenesis and biology in general and can lead to transformation of medicine.

por.por_cntn:
This was a theoretical physics work on the problem of the "meter stick" 
of biology - the question of how living things measure out the many 
lengths required to construct their bodies.  This remains an unsolved 
problem over a century after D'Arcy Thompson first published his 
treatise on biological growth and form.  The central idea behind the 
work was that the length mensuration system of life must involve TIME.  
The argument that this is so involves elementary physics considerations 
of chemical reactions plus the observation that the length mensuration 
machinery of life, whatever it is, is extremely plastic and works over a 
wide range of scales. The empirical case for the existence of such 
measuration machinery has remained weak (nonexistent) for so long simply 
because (2) the powerful tools of biochemistry are all slow and (2) the 
signals are small.

The research produced a single work: R. B. Laughlin, "Critical Waves and 
the Length Problem of Biology," Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci. (USA) 112, 10371 
(2015).  This paper explained the above ideas and then proceeded to 
demonstrate the engineering principles by which reaction-diffusion waves 
could be stabilized.  It had been known since the work of Turing that 
chemical reactions can easily manufacture such waves, which are 
propagating disturbances, like a chain of falling dominoes, that are 
powered by engines, as opposed waves of sound or light, which involve 
only inertia and passive forces.  But reaction-diffusion systems are 
notoriously unstable. The literature on them mostly concerns the 
fantastic patterns they produce. Biology can easily eliminate this this 
problem by just throwing out all the reaction-diffusion systems that "do 
not work". This paper showed what the engineering principle was by which 
they could do so and cause the "well engineered" waves to act exactly 
like waves of sound or light. The trick is simply to turn the engine 
"gain" up until the system almost oscillates.  This particular 
engineering principle is known to be operating in the cochlea. It is the 
reason that a microphone placed near an ear detects sound emanating from 
it. Once one has constructed a propagating disturbance with a fixed 
speed scale, one can measure out lengths by echo timing or by standing 
wave frequency resonance detection, like a laser.  The latter is the 
principle that enables electron waves to measure out the sizes of atoms.  
The different in this case is that the waves are manufactors by the 
living system itself, rather than existing in the natural world in the 
absence of life.

The work then went further to make a prediction that chemical potential 
waves of this nature should be present in eucaryotic cells undergoing 
mitosis.  The argument rested partly on observations made by others 
(including Thompson) that mitotic spindle patterns look like dipole 
oscillations of sound in a round enclosure. Cell division involves length 
mensuration, and it is very ancient and highly conserved, so this is a 
good place to look for engineering principles that work. But the 
argument also used the fact that chemical oscillations of exactly this 
form had been observed in E Coli 15 years before, and were known to be 
central to locating the midpoint for cell devision.

Subsequent to the publication of this work, chemical potential waves of 
the predicted nature were experimentally discovered in a eukaryotic cell 
undergoing mitosis: S. Xiao et al., "Mitotic Cortial Waves Predict 
Future Division Sites by Encoding Positional and Size Information," 
Developmental Cell 43, 493 (2017).  Xiao et al cited the work of this 
research as central to the analysis, and they made the case that timing, 
not speed scale, was changing when the cell size upon division changed.
